title: Consider shared interface for ExtismHost and PluginHost

- LoadPlugin(ctx, name, []byte) error

- Close(ctx) error

- [ ] If no: document why duplication is acceptable
- [ ] Independent subagent review before closing

title: Add closed-state check to HasPlugin for defensive consistency
description:
## Summary
HasPlugin does not check closed state, unlike other ExtismHost methods.

## Problem
After Close() is called, h.plugins is set to nil. HasPlugin returns false (correct behavior) but doesn't explicitly check h.closed like LoadPlugin and DeliverEvent do.

## Solution
Add closed-state check to HasPlugin for defensive consistency:
```go
func (h *ExtismHost) HasPlugin(name string) bool {
    h.mu.RLock()
    defer h.mu.RUnlock()
    if h.closed {
        return false
    }
    _, ok := h.plugins[name]
    return ok
}
```

## Files
- Modify: internal/wasm/extism_host.go

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] HasPlugin checks h.closed before accessing plugins map
- [ ] Test: `TestExtismHost_HasPlugin_AfterClose` verifies behavior
- [ ] Consistent with LoadPlugin and DeliverEvent patterns

title: Wire Broadcaster to push real-time events to connected clients

- ConnectionHandler processes commands and sends responses
- Events are persisted to EventStore
- Events are replayed on reconnect

- Need to wire: Engine -> Broadcaster -> ConnectionHandlers

## Implementation
1. ConnectionHandler subscribes to location stream on connect
2. Engine publishes events to Broadcaster after persisting
3. Broadcaster delivers to all subscribed ConnectionHandlers
4. ConnectionHandler.sendEvent() formats and sends to client

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Two telnet clients connected to same location

title: Consider goroutine leak during slow plugin + context cancellation
description:
## Problem
extism_subscriber.go:105-121 uses a timeout derived from parent context. If parent context is cancelled (during shutdown), DeliverEvent may still block for up to 5 seconds if Extism SDK does not respect context cancellation internally.

## Source
PR Review Round 7 - code-reviewer agent (Confidence: 85)

comments.author: seanb4t
comments.text:
## Investigation Complete

### Findings

1. **Extism SDK does NOT respect context cancellation during WASM execution**
   - `CallWithContext` does not interrupt in-flight WASM calls when context is cancelled
   - The call runs to completion regardless of context state

2. **This is NOT a problem for goroutine leaks** because:
   - WASM compilation (LoadPlugin) is slow (~1.5s) but happens once
   - Plugin calls (DeliverEvent) after compilation are **very fast (~1-2ms)**
   - Even without context cancellation, calls complete almost immediately
   - The `deliveryTimeout` (default 5s) provides a safety boundary for stuck plugins
   - `ExtismSubscriber.Stop()` waits for in-flight deliveries via WaitGroup

3. **Changes made:**
   - Switched from `p.Call()` to `p.CallWithContext(ctx, ...)` for future-proofing
   - Added comprehensive test `TestExtismHost_DeliverEvent_ContextCancellation` documenting behavior
   - Test verifies calls complete in <3s even with cancelled contexts

### Recommendation
No further action needed. The current implementation is safe.

title: Investigate Python PDK plugin reuse state corruption
description:
## Summary
When the Python echo plugin is called multiple times in rapid succession within the same ExtismHost, wasm memory errors occur:
- `out of bounds memory access`
- `invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference`

The Rust alloc plugin handles reuse fine, suggesting this is Python PDK-specific.

## Impact
- Plugins may need to be single-use or require host instance isolation
- Could affect production plugin reliability under load

## Investigation Tasks
- [ ] Determine if this is Extism Go SDK behavior or Python PDK behavior
- [ ] Test with other PDKs (Rust, JavaScript) for comparison
- [ ] Check Extism documentation for plugin instance lifecycle
- [ ] Determine if `plugin.Reset()` or similar is needed between calls
- [ ] Document findings and recommended patterns

## Workarounds
- Use separate ExtismHost instances per plugin (current test approach)
- Avoid rapid sequential calls to same plugin

## References
- Observed in TestExtismSubscriber_MultiplePatterns test
- Related epic: holomush-qmt (Extism Phase 1)
close_reason: Investigation complete: Confirmed NOT Python-specific. Root cause is fundamental WASM limitation - linear memory shared between host/guest allows only one concurrent caller per plugin instance. Evidence: Philippe Charrière blog post demonstrated same crash with Rust plugin; Steve Manuel (Extism CEO) confirmed mutex protection needed. Documented findings in CLAUDE.md and plugin-authoring.md. HoloMUSH ExtismSubscriber already handles this correctly via serialized delivery.

title: Add goroutine lifecycle management to ExtismSubscriber
description:
## Summary
ExtismSubscriber spawns goroutines without lifecycle management, risking goroutine leaks on shutdown.

## Problem
HandleEvent spawns goroutines for each plugin but has no:
- WaitGroup to track in-flight deliveries
- Stop() method to wait for goroutines
- Context propagation for cancellation

Compare to wazero PluginSubscriber which has proper Start()/Stop() lifecycle.

## Solution
Add lifecycle management:
```go
type ExtismSubscriber struct {
    // ... existing fields
    wg     sync.WaitGroup
    ctx    context.Context
    cancel context.CancelFunc
}

func (s *ExtismSubscriber) Stop() {
    s.cancel()
    s.wg.Wait()
}
```

## Files
- Modify: internal/wasm/extism_subscriber.go
- Modify: internal/wasm/extism_subscriber_test.go

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] ExtismSubscriber has Stop() method that waits for in-flight deliveries
- [ ] Test: `TestExtismSubscriber_Stop_WaitsForInFlight` verifies clean shutdown
- [ ] No goroutine leaks verified with `goleak` or similar

title: Fix thread safety: hold RLock during entire DeliverEvent call
description:
## Summary
ExtismHost.DeliverEvent releases the RLock before using the plugin pointer, creating a race condition if Close() is called concurrently.

## Problem
```go
h.mu.RLock()
p, ok := h.plugins[pluginName]
h.mu.RUnlock()  // Lock released before using p

if \!ok { ... }
if \!p.FunctionExists("handle_event") { ... }  // p used outside lock
```

If Close() is called after RUnlock() but before p.Call(), the plugin could be invalidated.

## Solution
Hold the read lock for the entire DeliverEvent call, consistent with wazero PluginHost pattern.

## Files
- Modify: internal/wasm/extism_host.go

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] RLock held from plugin lookup through p.Call() completion
- [ ] Test: `TestExtismHost_DeliverEvent_ConcurrentClose` demonstrates no race
- [ ] Run with `go test -race` passes
- [ ] Code review confirms fix
close_reason: Fixed: RLock now held for entire DeliverEvent call. Test: TestExtismHost_DeliverEvent_ConcurrentClose passes with -race
